elements.name: Hydrogen
elements.summary: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless gas.

elements.name: Helium
elements.summary: Helium is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert, monatomic gas that heads the noble gas series.

elements.name: Lithium
elements.summary: Lithium is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal. It is the lightest solid element.

elements.name: Beryllium
elements.summary: Beryllium is a steel-gray, strong, lightweight and brittle alkaline earth metal.

elements.name: Boron
elements.summary: Boron is a metalloid that exists in several allotropes including amorphous and crystalline forms.
elements.discovered_by: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac, Louis Jacques Thénard

elements.name: Carbon
elements.summary: Carbon is a versatile element that forms more compounds than any other element, with almost ten million compounds described.

elements.name: Nitrogen
elements.summary: Nitrogen is a colorless, odorless, tasteless diatomic gas that makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

elements.name: Oxygen
elements.summary: Oxygen is a highly reactive nonmetal and oxidizing agent that readily forms compounds with most elements.

elements.name: Fluorine
elements.summary: Fluorine is the most reactive and electronegative of all elements, and is a pale yellow diatomic gas.

elements.name: Neon
elements.summary: Neon is a colorless, odorless, inert monatomic gas that gives a distinct reddish-orange glow when used in discharge tubes.

elements.name: Sodium
elements.summary: Sodium is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive alkali metal.

elements.name: Magnesium
elements.summary: Magnesium is a shiny gray solid which bears a close physical resemblance to the other five elements in the second column.

elements.name: Aluminum
elements.summary: Aluminum is a silvery-white, soft, nonmagnetic and ductile metal in the boron group.

elements.name: Silicon
elements.summary: Silicon is a hard and brittle crystalline solid with a blue-grey metallic lustre.

elements.name: Phosphorus
elements.summary: Phosphorus exists in two major forms, white phosphorus and red phosphorus, but because it is highly reactive, phosphorus is never found as a free element on Earth.

elements.name: Sulfur
elements.summary: Sulfur is a bright yellow, crystalline solid at room temperature.

elements.name: Chlorine
elements.summary: Chlorine is a yellow-green gas that is a strong oxidizing agent.

elements.name: Argon
elements.summary: Argon is a noble gas, the third-most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere.

elements.name: Potassium
elements.summary: Potassium is a silvery-white metal that is soft enough to be cut with a knife with little force.

elements.name: Calcium
elements.summary: Calcium is an alkaline earth metal; it is a reactive pale-yellow metal that forms a dark oxide-nitride layer when exposed to air.

elements.name: Scandium
elements.summary: Scandium is a silvery-white metallic d-block element. It has historically been classified as a rare-earth element.

elements.name: Titanium
elements.summary: Titanium is a lustrous transition metal with a silver color, low density, and high strength.

elements.name: Vanadium
elements.summary: Vanadium is a hard, silvery-grey, malleable transition metal.

elements.name: Chromium
elements.summary: Chromium is a steely-grey, lustrous, hard and brittle transition metal.

elements.name: Manganese
elements.summary: Manganese is a transition metal with a multifaceted array of industrial alloy uses, particularly in stainless steels.

elements.name: Iron
elements.summary: Iron is by mass the most common element on Earth, forming much of Earth's outer and inner core.
elements.color: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

elements.name: Cobalt
elements.summary: Cobalt is found in the Earth's crust only in chemically combined form, save for small deposits found in alloys of natural meteoric iron.

elements.name: Nickel
elements.summary: Nickel is a silvery-white lustrous metal with a slight golden tinge.

elements.name: Copper
elements.summary: Copper is a soft, malleable, and ductile metal with very high thermal and electrical conductivity.

elements.name: Zinc
elements.summary: Zinc is a slightly brittle metal at room temperature and has a blue-silvery appearance when oxidation is removed.

elements.name: Gallium
elements.summary: Gallium is a soft, silvery metal. Elemental gallium is a brittle solid at low temperatures, and melts at 29.76°C (85.57°F).

elements.name: Germanium
elements.summary: Germanium is a lustrous, hard-brittle, grayish-white metalloid in the carbon group.

elements.name: Arsenic
elements.summary: Arsenic occurs in many minerals, usually in combination with sulfur and metals, but also as a pure elemental crystal.

elements.name: Selenium
elements.summary: Selenium is a nonmetal with properties that are intermediate between the elements above and below in the periodic table, sulfur and tellurium.

elements.name: Bromine
elements.summary: Bromine is a fuming red-brown liquid at room temperature that evaporates readily to form a similarly coloured gas.

elements.name: Krypton
elements.summary: Krypton is a colorless, odorless, tasteless noble gas that occurs in trace amounts in the atmosphere and is often used with other rare gases in fluorescent lamps.

elements.name: Rubidium
elements.summary: Rubidium is a soft, silvery-white metallic element of the alkali metal group.

elements.name: Strontium
elements.summary: Strontium is a highly reactive alkaline earth metal that forms a dark oxide layer when exposed to air.

elements.name: Yttrium
elements.summary: Yttrium is often found in combination with lanthanide elements in rare-earth minerals.

elements.name: Zirconium
elements.summary: Zirconium is a lustrous, grey-white, strong transition metal that resembles hafnium and, to a lesser extent, titanium.

elements.name: Niobium
elements.summary: Niobium is a soft, grey, crystalline, ductile transition metal.

elements.name: Molybdenum
elements.summary: Molybdenum is a silvery-grey metal; it has the sixth-highest melting point of any element.

elements.name: Technetium
elements.summary: Technetium is the lowest atomic number element without any stable isotopes; every form of it is radioactive.

elements.name: Ruthenium
elements.summary: Ruthenium is a rare transition metal belonging to the platinum group of the periodic table.

elements.name: Rhodium
elements.summary: Rhodium is a rare, silvery-white, hard, corrosion-resistant, and chemically inert transition metal.

elements.name: Palladium
elements.summary: Palladium is a rare and lustrous silvery-white metal discovered in 1803 by William Hyde Wollaston.

elements.name: Silver
elements.summary: Silver is a soft, white, lustrous transition metal, it exhibits the highest electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and reflectivity of any metal.

elements.name: Cadmium
elements.summary: Cadmium is a soft, bluish-white metal and is chemically similar to the two other stable metals in group 12, zinc and mercury.
elements.discovered_by: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann, Friedrich Stromeyer

elements.name: Indium
elements.summary: Indium is a post-transition metal that makes up about 0.21 parts per million of the Earth's crust. Indium is very soft and malleable.

elements.name: Tin
elements.summary: Tin is a silvery, malleable post-transition metal. Tin is obtained chiefly from the mineral cassiterite, where it occurs as tin dioxide.

elements.name: Antimony
elements.summary: Antimony is a lustrous gray metalloid, it is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite.

elements.name: Tellurium
elements.summary: Tellurium is a silvery-white, brittle, mildly toxic, rare, brittle metalloid.

elements.name: Iodine
elements.summary: Iodine is a chemical element with symbol I and atomic number 53. The heaviest of the stable halogens, it exists as a lustrous, purple-black metallic-looking solid at standard conditions.

elements.name: Xenon
elements.summary: Xenon is a colorless, dense, odorless noble gas, that occurs in the Earth's atmosphere in trace amounts.

elements.name: Cesium
elements.summary: Cesium is an alkali metal with physical and chemical properties similar to those of rubidium and potassium.

elements.name: Barium
elements.summary: Barium is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal. Because of its high chemical reactivity, barium is never found in nature as a free element.

elements.name: Lanthanum
elements.summary: Lanthanum is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metallic element that tarnishes rapidly when exposed to air.

elements.name: Cerium
elements.summary: Cerium is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metal that tarnishes when exposed to air, and it is soft enough to be cut with a knife.
elements.discovered_by: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius

elements.name: Praseodymium
elements.summary: Praseodymium is a soft, silvery, malleable and ductile metal in the lanthanide group.

elements.name: Neodymium
elements.summary: Neodymium is a soft silvery metal that tarnishes in air. Neodymium was discovered in 1885 by the Austrian chemist Carl Auer von Welsbach.

elements.name: Promethium
elements.summary: Promethium is the only radioactive lanthanide; used in atomic batteries.
elements.discovered_by: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Charles D. Coryell

elements.name: Samarium
elements.summary: Samarium is used in powerful permanent magnets (SmCo alloys).

elements.name: Europium
elements.summary: Europium is used in red phosphors for LED and CRT screens.

elements.name: Gadolinium
elements.summary: Gadolinium has the highest thermal neutron capture cross-section of any element.

elements.name: Terbium
elements.summary: Terbium is used in green phosphors and magnetostrictive alloys.

elements.name: Dysprosium
elements.summary: Dysprosium is used in hard drives and control rods in nuclear reactors.

elements.name: Holmium
elements.summary: Holmium has the highest magnetic moment of any element.

elements.name: Erbium
elements.summary: Erbium is used in fiber optic amplifiers and pink glass.

elements.name: Thulium
elements.summary: Thulium is the least abundant of the naturally occurring lanthanides.

elements.name: Ytterbium
elements.summary: Ytterbium is used as a dopant in laser crystals and stainless steel.

elements.name: Lutetium
elements.summary: Lutetium is the last lanthanide; used in PET scan detectors.
elements.discovered_by: Georges Urbain, Carl Auer von Welsbach

elements.name: Hafnium
elements.summary: Hafnium is used in nuclear control rods and microprocessors.

elements.name: Tantalum
elements.summary: Tantalum is highly corrosion-resistant; used in capacitors and medical implants.

elements.name: Tungsten
elements.summary: Tungsten has the highest melting point of any metal (3695 K).

elements.name: Rhenium
elements.summary: Rhenium is used in high-temperature superalloys for jet engines.
elements.discovered_by: Masataka Ogawa, Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack

elements.name: Osmium
elements.summary: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.

elements.name: Iridium
elements.summary: Iridium is the most corrosion-resistant metal known.

elements.name: Platinum
elements.summary: Platinum is used in jewelry, catalysts, and anti-cancer drugs.

elements.name: Gold
elements.summary: Gold is the most malleable and ductile metal known.

elements.name: Mercury
elements.summary: Mercury is the only metal liquid at standard room temperature.

elements.name: Thallium
elements.summary: Thallium is highly toxic; used in electronics and glass manufacturing.

elements.name: Lead
elements.summary: Lead is a dense metal used for radiation shielding and batteries.

elements.name: Bismuth
elements.summary: Bismuth is weakly radioactive; used in cosmetics and fire sprinklers.

elements.name: Polonium
elements.summary: Polonium is highly radioactive; used in anti-static brushes.

elements.name: Astatine
elements.summary: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element on Earth.
elements.discovered_by: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè

elements.name: Radon
elements.summary: Radon is a radioactive gas produced from uranium decay.

elements.name: Francium
elements.summary: Francium is an extremely unstable alkali metal.

elements.name: Radium
elements.summary: Radium was once used for luminous watches; it is highly radioactive.

elements.name: Actinium
elements.summary: Actinium glows with a blue light in the dark due to its radioactivity.

elements.name: Thorium
elements.summary: Thorium is a potential clean alternative to uranium for nuclear power.

elements.name: Protactinium
elements.summary: Protactinium is a dense, silvery-grey metal found in uranium ores.
elements.discovered_by: William Crookes, Kasimir Fajans, Otto Hahn

elements.name: Uranium
elements.summary: Uranium is the primary fuel for nuclear power reactors.

elements.name: Neptunium
elements.summary: Neptunium was the first transuranium element produced synthetically.

elements.name: Plutonium
elements.summary: Plutonium is used in nuclear weapons and space probe power sources.
elements.discovered_by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan

elements.name: Americium
elements.summary: Americium is found in ionization smoke detectors.
elements.discovered_by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso

elements.name: Curium
elements.summary: Curium is highly radioactive; named after Marie and Pierre Curie.
elements.discovered_by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso

elements.name: Berkelium
elements.summary: Berkelium is named after Berkeley, California.
elements.discovered_by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso

elements.name: Californium
elements.summary: Californium is used as a neutron source to start nuclear reactors.
elements.discovered_by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street, Jr., Albert Ghiorso

elements.name: Einsteinium
elements.summary: Einsteinium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb.

elements.name: Fermium
elements.summary: Fermium is the heaviest element that can be formed by neutron bombardment.

elements.name: Mendelevium
elements.summary: Mendelevium is named after the creator of the periodic table, Dmitri Mendeleev.
elements.discovered_by: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, et al.

elements.name: Nobelium
elements.summary: Nobelium is named after Alfred Nobel.

elements.name: Lawrencium
elements.summary: Lawrencium is the last actinide; all isotopes are very short-lived.

elements.name: Rutherfordium
elements.summary: Rutherfordium is the first transactinide element; synthetic and radioactive.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

elements.name: Dubnium
elements.summary: Dubnium was subject of the 'Transfermium Wars' naming dispute.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

elements.name: Seaborgium
elements.summary: Seaborgium was the first element named after a living person (Glenn T. Seaborg).
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

elements.name: Bohrium
elements.summary: Bohrium is named after physicist Niels Bohr.

elements.name: Hassium
elements.summary: Hassium is a synthetic element that forms a volatile tetroxide.

elements.name: Meitnerium
elements.summary: Meitnerium is named after nuclear fission pioneer Lise Meitner.

elements.name: Darmstadtium
elements.summary: Darmstadtium was discovered at the GSI Helmholtz Centre in Germany.

elements.name: Roentgenium
elements.summary: Roentgenium is named after Wilhelm Röntgen; it is a synthetic element that does not occur naturally.

elements.name: Copernicium
elements.summary: Copernicium is extremely radioactive and synthetic; it is predicted to be a volatile liquid metal at room temperature.

elements.name: Nihonium
elements.summary: Nihonium was first synthesized in 2003; the name comes from the Japanese word for Japan (Nihon).
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

elements.name: Flerovium
elements.summary: Flerovium is a superheavy synthetic element; it is named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

elements.name: Moscovium
elements.summary: Moscovium was first synthesized in 2003 by a joint team of Russian and American scientists.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

elements.name: Livermorium
elements.summary: Livermorium is named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the United States.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

elements.name: Tennessine
elements.summary: Tennessine is the second-heaviest known element; it belongs to the halogen group on the periodic table.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Oak Ridge National Laboratory

elements.name: Oganesson
elements.summary: Oganesson is currently the highest atomic number and highest atomic mass of all known elements.
elements.discovered_by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
